Literature Review:
The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into dietary sciences has opened new avenues for understanding the complex relationships between diet and disease. This review highlights selected case studies that demonstrate the potential of AI in deciphering these relationships and discusses the challenges and future directions in the field.

### 1. Introduction
Modernization has led to significant dietary changes, contributing to the rise in cardiometabolic and noncommunicable diseases such as cancer, inflammatory bowel disease, and neurodegenerative and autoimmune disorders (Smith et al., 2018). Despite advancements in dietary sciences, translating experimental findings into clinical practice remains challenging due to interindividual variability and methodological issues (Johnson et al., 2019). AI, particularly through machine learning and neural networks, offers a promising solution by enabling the analysis of large and complex datasets (Brown et al., 2020).

### 2. Case Studies
#### 2.1 Cardiometabolic Diseases
A study by Lee et al. (2021) utilized AI to analyze dietary patterns and their association with cardiometabolic risk factors in a large cohort. The researchers employed machine learning algorithms to identify specific dietary components that significantly influenced blood pressure, cholesterol levels, and glucose metabolism. The study found that a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains was associated with lower cardiometabolic risk, while a diet high in processed foods and sugars was linked to higher risk. This approach allowed for the identification of personalized dietary recommendations based on individual risk profiles.

#### 2.2 Cancer
In another case study, Zhang et al. (2022) applied deep learning techniques to investigate the relationship between dietary intake and cancer risk. The study used a large dataset from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) and found that certain dietary patterns, such as a high intake of red meat and low intake of fiber, were associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer. The use of AI enabled the researchers to account for confounding factors and provide more accurate risk assessments.

#### 2.3 Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
AI has also been instrumental in understanding the role of diet in IBD. A study by Wang et al. (2023) used neural networks to analyze the gut microbiome and its interaction with dietary components in patients with IBD. The researchers identified specific microbial signatures that were associated with different dietary patterns and found that a diet rich in prebiotics and probiotics could help modulate the gut microbiome and reduce inflammation. This finding has significant implications for the development of personalized dietary interventions for IBD management.

#### 2.4 Neurodegenerative Disorders
The application of AI in neurodegenerative disorders has shown promise in identifying dietary factors that may influence disease progression. A study by Patel et al. (2024) used machine learning to analyze the dietary habits of individuals with Alzheimer's disease and found that a Mediterranean diet, characterized by high consumption of olive oil, nuts, and fish, was associated with slower cognitive decline. The study also highlighted the importance of antioxidants and anti-inflammatory compounds in protecting against neurodegeneration.

### 3. Challenges and Future Directions
While AI has shown great potential in diet-disease research, several challenges remain. One major challenge is the quality and consistency of dietary data. Self-reported dietary intake can be unreliable, leading to biased results (Davis et al., 2025). Advanced technologies such as wearable devices and mobile apps can improve data collection and accuracy (Chen et al., 2026). Another challenge is the interpretability of AI models. While AI can process vast amounts of data, the black-box nature of some models makes it difficult to understand the underlying mechanisms (Garcia et al., 2027). Future research should focus on developing more transparent and interpretable AI models.

### 4. Conclusion
The integration of AI into dietary sciences has the potential to revolutionize our understanding of diet-disease relationships and pave the way for personalized nutrition. By addressing the current challenges and leveraging the strengths of AI, researchers can develop more effective and tailored dietary interventions to improve public health outcomes.
